title: How to Treat an Oil Burn

steps.title: Move away from the source of the burn.
steps.content: Move away from the source of the burn. Stepping away from the hot oil keeps you from getting burned again. [2] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source Step far enough away that oil splatter won't reach you. You may also turn off the heat source if it is safe to do so. If you're cooking, cover the pan with a lid before you begin first aid treatment so you don’t cause a fire. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Remove any clothing near the burn.
steps.content: Remove any clothing near the burn. Before you cool the burn, remove any clothing or jewelry covering the burn, unless it's stuck to the burn. [4] X Research source If the clothing is stuck, leave it. Pulling it off could cause further damage to your skin. [5] X Research source If part of a piece of clothing is stuck to the burn, you may have to cut around it. Do not remove burned clothing that is stuck to your skin. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Run cool water over the burned skin for at least 5 minutes.
steps.content: Run cool water over the burned skin for at least 5 minutes. If you have a minor, first-degree burn, you can hold the area under cool running water. [7] X Research source Make sure the water is covering all parts of the burn. If the skin isn't cool to the touch after 5 minutes, you can continue running the water for up to 30 minutes. [8] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source The water should be cool, but not cold. Avoid applying ice to the burn because it can cause further tissue damage. [9] X Research source Wrap some plastic cling wrap around the burn after running water over it. This will keep the burn clean and help the area retain moisture. [10] X Research source If you can't run cool water over the burned skin due to the location of the burn, you can place a washcloth soaked in cool water over the burn, or soak the burn in a cool bath for 5 minutes. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Evaluate the size and appearance of the burn.
steps.content: Evaluate the size and appearance of the burn. If the burn is less than 3 inches in diameter, then you can probably treat it at home. [12] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source For larger burns, seek medical attention as soon as possible. [13] X Research source If your burn is deep and severe, you may notice blistering, redness, and inflammation and heat around the burn. These types of burns can cause nerve damage, and should be treated by a medical professional, even if they are small. [14] X Research source Call emergency services or go to the emergency room immediately if your burn covers a large area of your body (such as your face, hands, feet, or genitals), or is deep enough to penetrate all your layers of skin or deeper tissues. [15] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Take aspirin or acetaminophen for pain.
steps.content: Take aspirin or acetaminophen for pain. If the burn is still painful after you've cooled the skin, an over-the-counter pain reliever may help. [16] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source A pain reliever with an anti-inflammatory can also help reduce swelling. [17] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Clean the burn with cool water.
steps.content: Clean the burn with cool water. Use cool water to gently clean the skin. Pat, rather than rub, to avoid causing further damage to your skin. [18] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source If your skin is blistered, take extra care not to pop any of the blisters. [19] X Research source

steps.title: Apply a thin layer of burn ointment.
steps.content: Apply a thin layer of burn ointment. If you have a first aid kit, it may include a burn ointment. If you have an ointment or gel available, you can use it. However, it isn't necessary to use burn ointment or gel to treat an oil burn. [20] X Research source According to FAAD board certified dermatologist Mohiba Tareen, MD, you can also use “pure aloe to bring down inflammation.” [21] X Expert Source Mohiba Tareen, MD FAAD Board Certified Dermatologist Expert Interview. 26 March 2020. Avoid ointments that contain antibiotics. Antibiotics aren't necessary, and may cause an allergic reaction. Do not use creams, lotions, butter, or egg whites. They can prevent your skin from healing and may lead to infection. [22] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source

steps.title: Wrap the burn lightly with a moist dressing.
steps.content: Wrap the burn lightly with a moist dressing. If you can, use a moist dressing pad or wrap specifically designed for burns. Your dressing should be loose and secured with tape. [23] X Research source If you don't have burn dressing, you can wrap the burn area with plastic cling wrap or a clean plastic bag. [24] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source Never wrap a burn with something that could stick or leave fibers on the burned skin, such as a dry gauze dressing. [25] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source If you must put gauze on the burn, wet the dressing with sterile water or apply a layer of petroleum jelly to the burn before putting on the gauze. [26] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Get a tetanus shot if necessary.
steps.content: Get a tetanus shot if necessary. Tetanus bacteria can enter your body through burned skin. If it has been more than 5 years since your last tetanus shot, call your doctor or a nearby clinic to get a booster. [27] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source Minor burns usually heal with dressings and pain relief medication. However, if your skin is blistered or the burn is more severe, a tetanus shot can protect you. [28] X Research source

steps.title: Change the dressing
steps.content: Change the dressing daily. Every day, remove the old dressing and discard it. Wash the burn with mild soap and cool water. [29] X Research source While you're washing the burn, inspect your skin for signs of infection. If you see oozing or pus, or if you notice increased redness or swelling, seek medical treatment right away. These could be signs of infection. [30] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source Apart from changes to the burn itself, a fever or swollen lymph nodes are also signs of infection. Seek medical treatment if you have a fever higher than 100.4° F (38° C). [31] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source It may take 1 to 3 weeks for the wound to heal. If it hasn't healed in that time, seek medical attention. [32] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Avoid scratching burned skin.
steps.content: Avoid scratching burned skin. As a burn heals, it will likely itch. If you scratch it, you could further damage the skin as well as introduce bacteria that could lead to an infection. [33] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source Aloe vera gel can help ease the itching. [34] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Avoid cortisone or other anti-itch creams or lotions. They are not effective for burns and may prevent the burn from healing. [35] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source
